ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A better understanding of material science along with a reinvigorated commitment to Mechanical Engineering.
I learned a bit about materials science from reading papers in order to write the lab reports. I didn't develop any skills.

I was able to gain a hands-on understanding of the machinery and techniques used in material science and mechanical engineering research. I became familiar with core machines like DMA, TGA, Instron, etc. I also was able to gain more insight into the general research processes universally applicable across STEM.
Material science curriculum, as well as materials science lab equipment and other precision testing equipment.

The course's strong hands on approach to the concepts of Material Science also learned in MENG 285 allowed me to gain theoretical and practical knowledge of the field through conducting experiments. I learned about the operation of different testing equipment, various forms of data analysis, and how to write scientific laboratory reports.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Dr. Datye is not a good professor. He makes fun of students and criticizes other professors during class and lab. I didn't learn anything from the lecture slides because they were poorly made and poorly explained. Lab groups are assigned.

I enjoy the fact that all of the labs are connected by the fact that the same samples and specimens are examined in each lab. This makes it easy to compare different techniques that give data for the same quantity as well as confirm known behaviors of the material with multiple tests across multiple labs. Some places I could see the course improving is in getting better testing equipment. One example would be improved modulations on the Instron machine, we had to use a frankly incompetent friction testing setup that gave completely unusable data. It could also be useful to get access to machines capable of forging. In my final project lab for the class, I had the idea to research how Katanas use the technique of folding the hot steel to strain harden a material however Yale does not have any facilities to do high-temperature testing of alloys and metals. Thus my research was limited by Yale's low range testing capabilities.
Course was structured very well with periodic lab sections and lectures to learn concepts and testing machines.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No. I didn't learn much and it's unnecessarily stressful.
Yes, really helpful in thoroughly learning material science concepts.
